elements.content: The use and transformation of carbon dioxide as a C1 source into valuable chemical products using cheap industrial chemicals under mild reaction conditions fulfill the requirements of atom economy in the chemical industry. In this paper, two new silver-cluster-based frameworks were synthesized by incorporating thiourea on the backbone of the tripodal ligands. Given their large pores, high density of catalytic sites, and appropriate coordination geometries, these heterogeneous materials could be used as high-efficiency π-activation catalysts in the atom-economical cycloaddition of propargylamines with carbon dioxide. The loading of 0.1 mol % catalysts enabled the almost complete transformation of the propargylamines into oxazolidinones at atmospheric pressure and room temperature. DFT calculations show significant charge accumulation regions with π* symmetry on C atoms associated with the acetylene bond along the Ag–C directions and charge depletion regions with σ symmetry along the C–C direction, further supporting the important role of silver-cluster-based catalysts in π* activation of substrates for subsequent reactions with approaching CO2. The crystallinity of the frameworks allowed the structure of the encapsulated substrates and the interactions of the CC bonds in the active intermediates to be clearly observed. The recyclability and high turnover number of the cycloaddition reaction demonstrate the broad potential applications of these designed materials as π-activation catalysts for practical applications in the chemical industry.

elements.content: The development of catalytic synthetic methods that use benign reaction conditions and environmentally friendly substrates is a major endeavor in synthetic chemistry. Among these environmentally friendly and atom-economical reactions, π-activation catalysis of propargylamine cycloaddition with carbon dioxide is a powerful method used to construct valuable chemical motifs in the pharmaceutical and chemical industries (see the summary in the Supporting Information). Since carbon dioxide is a negative-cost, raw material resource, the incorporation of carbon dioxide into these chemicals does not result in any side products. In terms of facile recovery and the selectivity for various shapes and sizes, heterogeneous porous materials offer many advantages over both homogeneous and nonporous heterogeneous materials for adsorption separation and catalysis. With their periodic, open structures and controllable pores, metal–organic frameworks are appealing heterogeneous catalysts for the chemical fixation of carbon dioxide.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The development of catalytic synthetic methods that use benign reaction conditions and environmentally friendly substrates is a major endeavor in synthetic chemistry. Among these environmentally friendly and atom-economical reactions, π-activation catalysis of propargylamine cycloaddition with carbon dioxide is a powerful method used to construct valuable chemical motifs in the pharmaceutical and chemical industries (see the summary in the Supporting Information). Since carbon dioxide is a negative-cost, raw material resource, the incorporation of carbon dioxide into these chemicals does not result in any side products. In terms of facile recovery and the selectivity for various shapes and sizes, heterogeneous porous materials offer many advantages over both homogeneous and nonporous heterogeneous materials for adsorption separation and catalysis. With their periodic, open structures and controllable pores, metal-organic frameworks are appealing heterogeneous catalysts for the chemical fixation of carbon dioxide.

elements.content: Generally, the typical coordination-driven self-assembly procedure for the frameworks cannot control both the large pores and high density of catalytic sites; high pressures and temperatures are often required in these kinds of catalytic transformations of carbon dioxide into fine chemicals. A new synthetic strategy is highly desirable to efficiently activate the substrates and to fix carbon dioxide chemically under mild conditions. Of these reported coordination nodes to construct functonal coordination frameworks, clusters are some of the most important secondary building units in MOFs; the possibility of anchoring rich metal-based catalytic sites around the surface of the clusters and the potential to achieve large porous volumes of cluster-based metal–organic polymers suggested them to be promising heterogeneous catalysts for carbon dioxide conversion.

elements.content: By incorporating thiourea on a large tripodal linker, we describe herein a new crystal engineering strategy to control the formation of silver clusters with large pores and a high density of active sites (). Given the appropriate coordination of silver clusters, multiple hydrogen-bonding triggers, and intrinsic silver−π complexation, these designed materials exhibit a high efficiency for π-activation transformation of propargylamines and carbon dioxide into value-added oxazolidinones under mild conditions. The strong silver–sulfur bonds of cluster nodes provide excellent chemical stability and recyclability for potential practical applications. At the same time, the intrinsic crystallinity of the frameworks facilitates a deep structural analysis of the intermediates and provides knowledge of the π activation of the CC bonds.

Given the appropriate coordination of silver clusters, multiple hydrogen-bonding triggers, and intrinsic silver-π complexation, these designed materials exhibit a high efficiency for π-activation transformation of propargylamines and carbon dioxide into value-added oxazolidinones under mild conditions. The strong silver-sulfur bonds of cluster nodes provide excellent chemical stability and recyclability for potential practical applications. At the same time, the intrinsic crystallinity of the frameworks facilitates a deep structural analysis of the intermediates and provides knowledge of the π activation of the CC bonds.

elements.content: The ligand H3L1 was prepared from a Schiff base reaction of thiosemicarbazide and the relevant tripodal ketone in high yield. Slowly diffusing AgBF4 into an H3L1 solution produces TNS-Ag8, which crystallized in the Pa3̅ space group (). The silver clusters exhibit D 3d symmetry with one of the silver atoms on the crystallographic 3-fold axis. Each silver atom coordinates to three S atoms from three different ligands, and the silver atom is located at the center of the plane of the S atoms. This specific coordination is important for the π complexation between the silver atoms and the alkyne derivatives. Each S atom is located at an edge of the cubic silver cluster and bridges two silver atoms. Twelve ligands coordinate to one cluster and divide into six pairs; the ligands in each pair stack together and function as a 2-fold linker to connect three different silver clusters. The silver clusters are regarded as 6-connection nodes that consolidate the three-dimensional frameworks with C 3-symmetric organic linkers. Two types of pores are observed in this structure. The cross-sectional area of the channel is 9.0 × 9.0 Å2 (Figure S4), which is large enough to absorb substrate molecules and provides the possibility of catalyzing the transformation of alkyne derivatives. Twenty-four H-bonding donors (−NH2 and −NH−) and 24 H-bonding acceptors (CN– and sulfur) are distributed on the surface of the silver clusters, and the donors and acceptors provide potential hydrogen-bonding interactions with substrates for synergistic activation and fixation during catalytic transformation.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structure of TNS-Ag8

The ligand H3L1 was prepared from a Schiff base reaction of thiosemicarbazide and the relevant tripodal ketone in high yield. Slowly diffusing AgBF4 into an H3L1 solution produces TNS-Ag8, which crystallized in the Pa3̅ space group (). The silver clusters exhibit D 3d  symmetry with one of the silver atoms on the crystallographic 3-fold axis. Each silver atom coordinates to three S atoms from three different ligands, and the silver atom is located at the center of the plane of the S atoms. This specific coordination is important for the π complexation between the silver atoms and the alkyne derivatives. Each S atom is located at an edge of the cubic silver cluster and bridges two silver atoms. Twelve ligands coordinate to one cluster and divide into six pairs; the ligands in each pair stack together and function as a 2-fold linker to connect three different silver clusters. The silver clusters are regarded as 6-connection nodes that consolidate the three-dimensional frameworks with C 3-symmetric organic linkers. Two types of pores are observed in this structure. The cross-sectional area of the channel is 9.0 × 9.0 Å2 (Figure S4), which is large enough to absorb substrate molecules and provides the possibility of catalyzing the transformation of alkyne derivatives. Twenty-four H-bonding donors (-NH2 and -NH-) and 24 H-bonding acceptors (CN- and sulfur) are distributed on the surface of the silver clusters, and the donors and acceptors provide potential hydrogen-bonding interactions with substrates for synergistic activation and fixation during catalytic transformation.

elements.content: TOS-Ag4 was prepared in a manner analogous to that for TNS-Ag8, except that H3L1 was replaced by H3L2. TOS-Ag4 crystallizes in the P213 space group (). Two asymmetric, independent, tetrahedral clusters were identified, and each cluster acts as a 3-connection node for the construction of a 2-fold interpenetrated, three-dimensional framework. The clusters possess C 3 symmetry with one silver atom on the crystallographic 3-fold axis. A weak but significant Ag···Ag interaction is evidenced by a Ag···Ag separation of 3.24 Å, and this interaction was further confirmed by the presence of a low-energy absorption band (50–120 cm–1) in the Raman spectrum (Figure S27). Each silver atom coordinates to three S atoms from three different ligands, and the silver atom is located in the center of the plane formed by the three S atoms. Each S atom is located at one edge of the tetrahedron and bridges two silver atoms. The six ligands linked to one cluster are divided into three pairs, and the ligands in each pair are stacked together and function as 2-fold bridges for three different silver clusters. In this case, the silver clusters are considered 3-connection nodes that consolidate the 3D framework with an srs-type topology. The cross-sectional area of the channel of 10.0 × 10.0 Å2 (Figure S5) in this interpenetration framework is large enough to accommodate substrate molecules. Similar to the case for TNS-Ag8, 12 H-bonding donors (−NH2 and −NH−) and 12 H-bonding acceptors (−CN– and sulfur) are distributed on the surface of each silver cluster. The specific silver-cluster-based frameworks control the formation of both the high density of active sites and the large pores by incorporating thiourea on the large tripodal linkers, and these traits facilitate the cycloaddition of propargylamines under mild conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Structure of TOS-Ag4

TOS-Ag4 was prepared in a manner analogous to that for TNS-Ag8, except that H3L1 was replaced by H3L2. TOS-Ag4 crystallizes in the P213 space group (). Two asymmetric, independent, tetrahedral clusters were identified, and each cluster acts as a 3-connection node for the construction of a 2-fold interpenetrated, three-dimensional framework. The clusters possess C 3 symmetry with one silver atom on the crystallographic 3-fold axis. A weak but significant Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interaction is evidenced by a Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag separation of 3.24 Å, and this interaction was further confirmed by the presence of a low-energy absorption band (50-120 cm-1) in the Raman spectrum (Figure S27). Each silver atom coordinates to three S atoms from three different ligands, and the silver atom is located in the center of the plane formed by the three S atoms. Each S atom is located at one edge of the tetrahedron and bridges two silver atoms. The six ligands linked to one cluster are divided into three pairs, and the ligands in each pair are stacked together and function as 2-fold bridges for three different silver clusters. In this case, the silver clusters are considered 3-connection nodes that consolidate the 3D framework with an srs-type topology. The cross-sectional area of the channel of 10.0 × 10.0 Å2 (Figure S5) in this interpenetration framework is large enough to accommodate substrate molecules. Similar to the case for TNS-Ag8, 12 H-bonding donors (-NH2 and -NH-) and 12 H-bonding acceptors (-CN- and sulfur) are distributed on the surface of each silver cluster. The specific silver-cluster-based frameworks control the formation of both the high density of active sites and the large pores by incorporating thiourea on the large tripodal linkers, and these traits facilitate the cycloaddition of propargylamines under mild conditions.

elements.content: The two silver-cluster-based frameworks that were developed exhibit both a high density of active sites and large pores, and these characteristics were achieved by incorporating appropriate silver–sulfur cluster nodes and large tripodal ligands. Because of the strong silver–sulfur bonds, these silver-based materials have good chemical stability. For the two resultant MOFs, the Ag4S6 cluster can be considered as half of the Ag8S12 cluster, and while each Ag8S12 cluster acted as a 6-connection node, each Ag4S6 cluster acted as a 3-connection node. The increase in the node connections always results in a decrease in the pore volume. In this case, the suitable size of the clusters allows the porous frameworks to exhibit a desirable catalytic efficiency.

Because of the strong silver-sulfur bonds, these silver-based materials have good chemical stability. For the two resultant MOFs, the Ag4S6 cluster can be considered as half of the Ag8S12 cluster, and while each Ag8S12 cluster acted as a 6-connection node, each Ag4S6 cluster acted as a 3-connection node. The increase in the node connections always results in a decrease in the pore volume. In this case, the suitable size of the clusters allows the porous frameworks to exhibit a desirable catalytic efficiency.

elements.content: The thermal stabilities of the synthesized materials were confirmed by thermogravimetric analysis (Figure S14). The solvent-accessible spaces were about 33000 and 33900 Å3 per unit cell (75.6% and 73.6% of the cell volume) as calculated by PLATON for TOS-Ag4 and TNS-Ag8, respectively. The dye-uptake studies were performed by soaking the silver-based frameworks in a methanol solution containing 2′,7′-dichlorofluorescein. Quantitative uptakes of 12.4% (w/w) and 12.6% (w/w) were observed for TOS-Ag4 and TNS-Ag8, respectively (Table S4). The diffusion behavior of dye molecules in both TNS-Ag8 and TOS-Ag4 were studied by UV–vis spectra (see Figure S23). The continuous adsorption and release profile reflected the diffusion behavior of dye molecules confined in pores. The release rate is much slower than the adsorption rate. It is speculated that the different diffusion behavior between release and adsorption profiles is caused by the interaction between pores and guest molecules. The adsorption rates (or release rates) in TNS-Ag8 and TOS-Ag4 is similar, which is consistent with the similar pore sizes and solvent-accessible spaces. Depth-scanning confocal laser scanning microscopy of the dye-adsorbed crystals revealed a strong fluorescence response that was attributable to the fluorescent dye. The uniform distribution of the dye molecules throughout the crystals suggests that the dyes deeply penetrate the channels instead of remaining on the external surface (Figure S24). These results indicate that substrates with suitable sizes can be adsorbed within the pores of the frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Characterizations and Catalytic Experiments

The thermal stabilities of the synthesized materials were confirmed by thermogravimetric analysis (Figure S14). The solvent-accessible spaces were about 33000 and 33900 Å3 per unit cell (75.6% and 73.6% of the cell volume) as calculated by PLATON for TOS-Ag4 and TNS-Ag8, respectively. The dye-uptake studies were performed by soaking the silver-based frameworks in a methanol solution containing 2',7'-dichlorofluorescein. Quantitative uptakes of 12.4% (w/w) and 12.6% (w/w) were observed for TOS-Ag4 and TNS-Ag8, respectively (Table S4). The diffusion behavior of dye molecules in both TNS-Ag8 and TOS-Ag4 were studied by UV-vis spectra (see Figure S23). The continuous adsorption and release profile reflected the diffusion behavior of dye molecules confined in pores. The release rate is much slower than the adsorption rate. It is speculated that the different diffusion behavior between release and adsorption profiles is caused by the interaction between pores and guest molecules. The adsorption rates (or release rates) in TNS-Ag8 and TOS-Ag4 is similar, which is consistent with the similar pore sizes and solvent-accessible spaces. Depth-scanning confocal laser scanning microscopy of the dye-adsorbed crystals revealed a strong fluorescence response that was attributable to the fluorescent dye. The uniform distribution of the dye molecules throughout the crystals suggests that the dyes deeply penetrate the channels instead of remaining on the external surface (Figure S24). These results indicate that substrates with suitable sizes can be adsorbed within the pores of the frameworks.

elements.content: The catalytic experiments initially focused on the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide and a simple propargylamine, N-methylpropargylamine (1a). The reaction was conducted in a 10 mL Schlenk tube with 0.8 mmol of 1a and CO2 under atmospheric pressure at 25 °C (conditions A). In the presence of 0.08 mmol (10.0 mol %) of 1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]­undec-7-ene (DBU), a 1 mol % (per mole of Ag atoms) loading of the catalyst afforded a nearly complete conversion of the aforementioned reaction within 24 h ( and ). Control experiments indicated that other standard silver catalysts (AgOTf, Ag2O, AgNO3, AgI, AgOAc, AgCF3COO, and AgBF4) and the Ag2S solid provided low yields or trace products with the same amount of catalysts (Table S2). The substrates were limited to terminal alkynes, and phenyl-substituted propargylamines were inactive due to their large steric hindrance. No detectable conversion occurred without the catalysts, and the reaction was terminated if the catalyst was filtered out (Figure S10). These results suggest that the use of silver-cluster-based porous frameworks is a promising approach to get silver-based catalysts for the π activation of CC bonds and the heterogeneous chemical fixation of CO2.

The catalytic reactions were conducted under conditions A: 1 mol % of catalyst (based on Ag, 3.7 mg for TNS-Ag8 and 4.2 mg for TOS-Ag4), 0.8 mmol of propargylamine, 0.08 mmol (10 mol %) of DBU, 3 mL of acetonitrile, 25 °C, and 0.1 MPa CO2 for 24 h. elements.content: The similar powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the as-synthesized crystals, the postcatalysis crystals, and the crystals immersed in water, propargylamines, and DBU confirm that the framework topology was maintained. Recycling experiments revealed the stability of the catalysts after five uses (Figure S9). Scale-up catalysis experiments were performed by adding an excess of the propargylamine, and no other reaction conditions were altered. The total turnover number value for TOS-Ag4 was 930 per mole of silver atoms (760 per mole of Ag atoms for TNS-Ag8, ). This catalytic system represents the highest catalytic efficiency reported, in comparison with other homogeneous or heterogeneous catalytic systems, for the cycloaddition of propargylamines (see ref and the summary in the Supporting Information). The obvious difference in the catalytic effects is ascribed to the higher dispersity of the active sites and the larger active surface in TOS-Ag4 than in TNS-Ag8, given the similar coordination of clusters and the similar diffusion behaviors in the two catalysts.

elements.content: The dye-uptake studies of the recovered catalysts revealed that the postcatalysis crystals exhibited 2,7′-dichlorofluorescein uptake abilities that were nearly identical with those of the as-synthesized catalysts under typical reaction conditions (Table S4). The depth-scanning laser scanning confocal images of the postcatalysis crystals indicated a uniform distribution of the dye throughout the materials (, top picture). PXRD patterns of postcatalysis crystals are similar to those of as-synthesized crystals. These results confirm that the porosity is maintained after the catalysis transformation. Most importantly, only a slight decrease in the catalytic activity was observed after 84 h for TOS-Ag4, and no detectable silver cations were dissolved in the solution on the basis of a typical qualitative analysis for silver cations in solution (Figure S12). These results demonstrated the excellent activity and stability of the delicately constructed silver–sulfur clusters. The recyclability and high turnover number of these π-activation catalysts suggest their broad potential for practical applications.

elements.content: The strong interactions between the propargylamines and our catalysts are significant factors in the catalytic conversion enhancement. The Raman spectra of the catalyst crystals that had adsorbed CO2 include a new peak at 1249 cm–1 that corresponds to the symmetrical stretch of CO in CO2 molecules. In comparison with the symmetrical CO stretch of free CO2 (1388 cm–1), the red shift in the peak suggests that the CO2 was activated by the amino groups around the silver atoms. The disappearance of the NH2 rocking vibration peak at 1441 cm–1 and the loss of the N–H stretching vibration peak at 3291 cm–1 confirm that CO2 was adsorbed and activated by the amino groups in the frameworks (, bottom, and Figure S16). The Raman spectra of the propargylamine 3a-impregnated catalysts exhibit a pronounced signal at ∼2100 cm–1 corresponding to the characteristic peak of the CC stretching vibration (Figures S17 and S18). In comparison with the CC stretching vibration peaks of 3a, the slight blue shift (approximately 20 cm–1) of the ν­(CH) stretching peak indicates that the interaction between the silver and the terminal alkyne is a π-bonding mode and not a σ-bonding mode (Figure S19). This result clearly supports our hypothesis that propargylamine is bound to the silver atoms via π bonds. The 1H NMR spectrum of propargylamine-impregnated crystals in the DMSO-d 6/thiourea solution exhibits the characteristic peaks of propargylamine. This result further indicates the adsorption of the substrates in the pores.
elements.clean_text:
Interactions for the Substrate Activation

The strong interactions between the propargylamines and our catalysts are significant factors in the catalytic conversion enhancement. The Raman spectra of the catalyst crystals that had adsorbed CO2 include a new peak at 1249 cm-1 that corresponds to the symmetrical stretch of CO in CO2 molecules. In comparison with the symmetrical CO stretch of free CO2 (1388 cm-1), the red shift in the peak suggests that the CO2 was activated by the amino groups around the silver atoms. The disappearance of the NH2 rocking vibration peak at 1441 cm-1 and the loss of the N-H stretching vibration peak at 3291 cm-1 confirm that CO2 was adsorbed and activated by the amino groups in the frameworks (, bottom, and Figure S16). The Raman spectra of the propargylamine 3a-impregnated catalysts exhibit a pronounced signal at ~2100 cm-1 corresponding to the characteristic peak of the CC stretching vibration (Figures S17 and S18). In comparison with the CC stretching vibration peaks of 3a, the slight blue shift (approximately 20 cm-1) of the ν(CH) stretching peak indicates that the interaction between the silver and the terminal alkyne is a π-bonding mode and not a σ-bonding mode (Figure S19). This result clearly supports our hypothesis that propargylamine is bound to the silver atoms via π bonds. The 1H NMR spectrum of propargylamine-impregnated crystals in the DMSO-d 6/thiourea solution exhibits the characteristic peaks of propargylamine. This result further indicates the adsorption of the substrates in the pores.

elements.content: Fortunately, the quality of the substrate 1a-impregnated crystals of TOS-Ag4 is sufficient for an X-ray structure analysis (denoted 1a@TOS-Ag4). As the most interesting mode shown in , one of the molecules of 1a interacts with the silver atoms and the primary amine groups within the inner surface of the framework. The intermolecular N···N separation of 3.41 Å and Ag···C separations of 2.78 and 3.17 Å (related to the two carbon atoms of the alkyne) directly demonstrate the π activation of propargylamine 1a during the catalysis. From a mechanistic point of view, the molecules of substrate 1a are trapped within the pores of the framework via hydrogen-bonding interactions relevant to the NH groups. The trapped molecules are then adjusted to suitable directions to allow the silver atoms to interact with the CC bond through π coordination to further activate the substrates. At the same time, the CO2 molecules interact with the NH groups, and the activated substrates react with CO2 to form the product through nucleophilic attack. The synergistic interaction mode of the π-activation and hydrogen-bonding interactions accelerates the capture of the substrates around the catalytic sites and catalyzes the chemical transformation under mild reaction conditions.

The trapped molecules are then adjusted to suitable directions to allow the silver atoms to interact with the CC bond through π coordination to further activate the substrates. At the same time, the CO2 molecules interact with the NH groups, and the activated substrates react with CO2 to form the product through nucleophilic attack. The synergistic interaction mode of the π-activation and hydrogen-bonding interactions accelerates the capture of the substrates around the catalytic sites and catalyzes the chemical transformation under mild reaction conditions.

elements.content: Spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) based calculations were performed to shed light on the mechanism that accounts for the proposed π activation of CC bonds. A cluster (a) was truncated from the TOS-Ag4 lattice and fully optimized with the GGA-PBE functional and DSPP pseudpotential as implemented within the DMol3 code. The van der Waals interactions were handled with the approach proposed by Reuter et al. We successfully reproduced the minimum Ag–Ag and Ag–S distances as 3.33 and 2.49 Å, respectively, which compare well with the experimental values of 3.26 and 2.47 Å, respectively. We then analyzed the potential interactions of propargylamine (PA) with the aforementioned TOS-Ag4 cluster. Among the binding configurations considered, PA adsorption with the acetylene bond is found to be plausible and the calculated E ad value per PA is as large as −1.16 eV (b). The DOS analysis (c) showed that, due to the interaction and charge transfer, all molecular states of PA hybridize strongly with the atomic states of Ag and are downshifted in comparison with their counterparts in the freestanding molecule. Specifically, there are strong resonance of the PA molecular states with the Ag atomic states in the energy range [−4.0, 0] eV and the PA π* states are split into parts and partially downshifted to below the Fermi level, showing that there is charge transfer from Ag for the activation of π* states. This is further confirmed by the significant charge accumulation regions with π* symmetry on C atoms associated with the acetylene bond in PA along the Ag–C directions and charge depletion regions with σ symmetry along the C–C direction and also on Ag. As a result, the acetylene C–C bond length within PA is elongated from 1.21 in the free molecule to 1.22 Å after adsorption. These visualize the important role of Ag in TOS-Ag4 in π* activation of PA for subsequent reactions with approaching CO2. PA adsorption with the amine group was also investigated but found to be ∼0.30 eV less plausible and was not examined further.

The Ag, S, C, N, H, and F atoms are shown in purple, yellow, gray, dark green, light pink, and blue, respectively in (a), (b), and (d). The charge accumulation region is in red and the charge depletion region is blue in (d), and the isosurface value is ±2 × 10–7 au.

elements.content: In summary, a new approach to control both the high density of the active sites and the large volume of the pores in the framework was reported for the π activation of propargylamines and the formation of oxazolidinones with CO2. This new crystal engineering strategy included the use of thiosemicarbazide moieties to control the formation of silver clusters and large tripodal linkers to connect the silver clusters into three-dimensional frameworks with large pores. The multiple H-bonding groups on the ligands accelerated the capture and activation of CO2 and propargyl-amines. The large pores and appropriate coordination of the silver clusters enabled an efficient catalytic transformation to occur under mild reaction conditions. The recyclability, high TON, and clear activation pathways of the cycloaddition reactions suggest broad potential applications in the chemical industry.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, a new approach to control both the high density of the active sites and the large volume of the pores in the framework was reported for the π activation of propargylamines and the formation of oxazolidinones with CO2. This new crystal engineering strategy included the use of thiosemicarbazide moieties to control the formation of silver clusters and large tripodal linkers to connect the silver clusters into three-dimensional frameworks with large pores. The multiple H-bonding groups on the ligands accelerated the capture and activation of CO2 and propargyl-amines. The large pores and appropriate coordination of the silver clusters enabled an efficient catalytic transformation to occur under mild reaction conditions. The recyclability, high TON, and clear activation pathways of the cycloaddition reactions suggest broad potential applications in the chemical industry.

elements.content: All chemicals were reagent grade quality and were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Carbon dioxide (99.995%) was purchased from Dalian Institute of Special Gases and was used as received. All manipulations involving air- and/or water-sensitive compounds were carried out under dry nitrogen using standard Schlenk techniques. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian INOVA 400 M spectrometer. 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian INOVA 500 M spectrometer. Tetramethysilane (TMS) served as the internal reference (δ 0) for 1H NMR. CDCl3-d 6 served as the internal reference (δ 77.16) for 13C NMR. FT-IR spectra were recorded using KBr pellets on a JASCO FT-IR-430 instrument. Diffuse reflectance FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Thermo Fisher-6700 instrument. The PXRD spectra were obtained on a Rigaku D/Max-2400 X-ray diffractometer with a Cu sealed tube (λ = 1.54178 Å). Raman spectroscopy (Lab Raman HR Evolution) measurements were performed using a solid-state 633 nm laser, and a laser power of 25% was used. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a Mettler-Toledo TGA/SDTA851 instrument and recorded under N2, with a ramp of 5 °C min–1 up to 1000 °C. Confocal laser scanning microscopy micrographs were collected using an Olympus Fluoview FV1000 instrument with λex 488 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Methods

Materials and Measurements

All chemicals were reagent grade quality and were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Carbon dioxide (99.995%) was purchased from Dalian Institute of Special Gases and was used as received. All manipulations involving air- and/or water-sensitive compounds were carried out under dry nitrogen using standard Schlenk techniques. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian INOVA 400 M spectrometer. 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian INOVA 500 M spectrometer. Tetramethysilane (TMS) served as the internal reference (δ 0) for 1H NMR. CDCl3-d 6 served as the internal reference (δ 77.16) for 13C NMR. FT-IR spectra were recorded using KBr pellets on a JASCO FT-IR-430 instrument. Diffuse reflectance FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Thermo Fisher-6700 instrument. The PXRD spectra were obtained on a Rigaku D/Max-2400 X-ray diffractometer with a Cu sealed tube (λ = 1.54178 Å). Raman spectroscopy (Lab Raman HR Evolution) measurements were performed using a solid-state 633 nm laser, and a laser power of 25% was used. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a Mettler-Toledo TGA/SDTA851 instrument and recorded under N2, with a ramp of 5 °C min-1 up to 1000 °C. Confocal laser scanning microscopy micrographs were collected using an Olympus Fluoview FV1000 instrument with λex 488 nm.

elements.content: Single crystals with suitable dimensions were selected under an optical microscope and placed into a glass tube filled with THF for data collection. The intensity data for all the crystals were collected at 170 K on a Bruker SMART APEX diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector and a Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation source. The data integration and reduction were processed using the SAINT software. An empirical absorption correction was applied to the collected reflection with SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXTL and refined on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares method using the program SHELXL-97.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Analysis

Single crystals with suitable dimensions were selected under an optical microscope and placed into a glass tube filled with THF for data collection. The intensity data for all the crystals were collected at 170 K on a Bruker SMART APEX diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector and a Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation source. The data integration and reduction were processed using the SAINT software. An empirical absorption correction was applied to the collected reflection with SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXTL and refined on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares method using the program SHELXL-97.

elements.content: For the crystal data of TOS-Ag4, both of the CF3COO– molecules were disordered into two parts. To help the stability of the refinement, bond distances between several atoms on benzene rings of the ligands, THF molecules, and CF3COO– anion were fixed, and some thermal parameters of the adjacent atoms on the ligand were restrained to be similar. For the crystal data of TNS-Ag8, one of the one-third occupied ligand molecules was disordered into two parts with the sof of each part being fixed as 0.5, respectively. To help the stability of the refinement, several constraints including the fixed bond distance of these disordered atoms were used. The geometrical constraints of idealized regular polygons were used for the disordered benzene ring, and thermal parameters on some adjacent atoms in the two molecules were restrained to be similar. For the crystal data of 1a@TOS-Ag4, one pair of ligand molecules was disordered into two parts with the sof of each part being fixed as 0.5, respectively. The geometrical constraints of idealized regular polygons were used for the disordered benzene ring, and thermal parameters on some adjacent atoms in the two molecules were restrained to be similar. The sof of two substrates was fixed as 0.33, and another substrate was disordered into two parts with the sof fixed as 0.5.

elements.content: We performed all of the density functional theory (DFT) based calculations with DMol3. All of the calculations were done with the GGA-PBE functional and DSPP pseudopotentials and DNP basis sets, and the potential van der Waals interactions were handled with the approach proposed by Reuter et al. We used a 35.22 × 35.22 × 35.22 Å3 orthogonal supercell and a 1 × 1 × 1 k-point grid for all of the calculations. The real-space global orbital cutoff radius was set to 4.7 Å and the convergence criteria for energy and forces were 3 × 10–4 eV and 3 × 10–2 eV/Å, respectively. All of the structures were fully relaxed with DMol3 and then subjected to population analysis with the Hirshfeld scheme.
elements.clean_text:
Density Functional Theory based Calculations

We performed all of the density functional theory (DFT) based calculations with DMol3. All of the calculations were done with the GGA-PBE functional and DSPP pseudopotentials and DNP basis sets, and the potential van der Waals interactions were handled with the approach proposed by Reuter et al. We used a 35.22 × 35.22 × 35.22 Å3 orthogonal supercell and a 1 × 1 × 1 k-point grid for all of the calculations. The real-space global orbital cutoff radius was set to 4.7 Å and the convergence criteria for energy and forces were 3 × 10-4 eV and 3 × 10-2 eV/Å, respectively. All of the structures were fully relaxed with DMol3 and then subjected to population analysis with the Hirshfeld scheme.

elements.content: The adsorption energy (E ad) of propargylamine (PA) onto TOS-Ag4 was calculated as the average energy difference between the relaxed PA-TOS-Ag4 composite and the relaxed clean TOS-Ag4 cluster plus the freestanding PA molecules, following the equation E ad = E PA ‐ TOS ‐ Ag 4 − ( n PA E PA + E TOS ‐ Ag 4 ) where n PA is the number of adsorbed PA molecules considered.

elements.content: In a glass tube, H3L1 (7 mg) was dissolved in DMF (1 mL) and then 1 mL of a DMF/CH3CN solution (1/5 v/v) was carefully layered followed by a layer of AgBF4 (6 mg) dissolved in CH3CN (1 mL). The container was covered and stored in the dark for the slow diffusion of the reactants at room temperature, to afford colorless or pale yellow crystals within 6 weeks. elements.content: The catalytic reactions were conducted in a 10 mL Schlenk tube with the selected catalyst (1 mol % based on Ag, 3.7 mg for TNS-Ag8 and 4.2 mg for TON-Ag4), 0.8 mmol of propargylamine, 0.08 mmol (10 mol %) of DBU, and 3 mL of acetonitrile as the solvent, and the reaction systems were purged by bubbling CO2 for 20 min. The vessel was immersed in an oil bath with stirring (250 rpm) at 25 °C under a 0.1 MPa CO2 atmosphere for 24 h. The yield of the reaction was calculated using the 1H NMR spectrum of the reaction mixture.

The yield of the reaction was calculated using the 1H NMR spectrum of the reaction mixture.

elements.content: In this scale-up catalytic experiment, the catalytic reaction was conducted in a 100 mL Schlenk tube with the selected catalyst (0.1 mol % based on Ag, 3.7 mg for TNS-Ag8 and 4.2 mg for TON-Ag4), 8 mmol of N-methylpropargylamine 1a, 0.8 mmol (10 mol %) of DBU, and 30 mL of acetonitrile as the solvent, and the reaction system was purged by bubbling CO2 for 20 min. The vessel was immersed in an oil bath with stirring (250 rpm) at 25 °C under a 0.1 MPa CO2 atmosphere for 24 h. Conditions B

In this scale-up catalytic experiment, the catalytic reaction was conducted in a 100 mL Schlenk tube with the selected catalyst (0.1 mol % based on Ag, 3.7 mg for TNS-Ag8 and 4.2 mg for TON-Ag4), 8 mmol of N-methylpropargylamine 1a, 0.8 mmol (10 mol %) of DBU, and 30 mL of acetonitrile as the solvent, and the reaction system was purged by bubbling CO2 for 20 min. Synthesis of TNS-Ag8

In a glass tube, H3L1 (7 mg) was dissolved in DMF (1 mL) and then 1 mL of a DMF/CH3CN solution (1/5 v/v) was carefully layered followed by a layer of AgBF4 (6 mg) dissolved in CH3CN (1 mL). The container was covered and stored in the dark for the slow diffusion of the reactants at room temperature, to afford colorless or pale yellow crystals within 6 weeks. The catalysts were soaked in tetrahydrofuran and ethyl ester for guest molecular exchange. Yield: 35 (based on Ag). Anal. Calcd for TNS-Ag8: C, 35.44; H, 4.16; N, 20.66; S, 10.25. Found: C, 36.31; H, 3.95; N, 21.13; S, 10.62.

Synthesis of 2,2′,2′′-((((1,3,5-Triazine-2,4,6-triyl)­tris­(oxy))­tris­(benzene-4,1-diyl))­tris­(methanylylidene))­tris­(hydrazinecarbothioamide) (H<sub>3</sub>L<sup>2</sup>)

2,4,6-Tris­(4-formyl phenoxy)-1,3,5-triazine (pre-L2) was synthesized according to the literature. Five drops of acetic acid were added to a mixture of pre-L2 (0.44 g, 1 mmol) and thiosemicarbazide (0.28 g, 3.1 mmol) in dry ethyl alcohol (25 mL). The mixture was refluxed overnight, and a white (or pale yellow) precipitate was isolated by filtration, washed with ethyl alcohol, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 0.65 g, 90%. 1H NMR [400 MHz, DMSO-d 6, ppm]: 11.46 (s, 1H, CH), 8.20 (s, 1H, -NH), 8.04 (s, 2H, -NH2), 7.87 (d, 2H, Ar-H), 7.31 (d, 2H, Ar-H).

Synthesis of TOS-Ag4

In a glass tube, H3L2 (6.6 mg) was dissolved in DMF (1 mL), and then 5 mL of a DMF/CH3CN solution (5/1 v/v) was carefully layered followed by a layer of AgCF3COO (6.6 mg) dissolved in CH3CN (1 mL). The container was covered and stored in the dark for the slow diffusion of reactants at room temperature, to afford colorless or pale yellow crystals within 6 weeks. Found: C, 32.75; H, 2.55; N, 15.14; S, 8.81.

Conditions A

The catalytic reactions were conducted in a 10 mL Schlenk tube with the selected catalyst (1 mol % based on Ag, 3.7 mg for TNS-Ag8 and 4.2 mg for TON-Ag4), 0.8 mmol of propargylamine, 0.08 mmol (10 mol %) of DBU, and 3 mL of acetonitrile as the solvent, and the reaction systems were purged by bubbling CO2 for 20 min. The vessel was immersed in an oil bath with stirring (250 rpm) at 25 °C under a 0.1 MPa CO2 atmosphere for 24 h. The yield of the reaction was calculated using the 1H NMR spectrum of the reaction mixture.

Conditions B

In this scale-up catalytic experiment, the catalytic reaction was conducted in a 100 mL Schlenk tube with the selected catalyst (0.1 mol % based on Ag, 3.7 mg for TNS-Ag8 and 4.2 mg for TON-Ag4), 8 mmol of N-methylpropargylamine 1a, 0.8 mmol (10 mol %) of DBU, and 30 mL of acetonitrile as the solvent, and the reaction system was purged by bubbling CO2 for 20 min. The vessel was immersed in an oil bath with stirring (250 rpm) at 25 °C under a 0.1 MPa CO2 atmosphere for 24 h. The yield of the reaction was calculated using the 1H NMR spectrum of the reaction mixture.
